awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Large Scale Cultivation of Phytoplankton via Novel Photo-Bioreactor Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will be to develop a sustainable, low-cost, and replicable method for large-scale production of micro-algal biomass. Microalgae production is a form of aquaculture capable of producing valuable products including nutraceuticals, specialty chemicals, pharmaceuticals, feed for finfish, shellfish, and livestock, as well as food for human consumption.  Moreover, it can be used as a feedstock for biofuels while simultaneously removing CO2 from the environment.  However, for algae cultivation to achieve its full commercial potential, the technology must be improved.  While typical algal cultivation relies on high-density cell growth, this project will focus on the science of low-density algal cultivation to achieve high productivity, while minimizing process requirements for supplemental energy and concentrated CO2.  In addition, the development of a closed-system photo-bioreactor with emphasis on low cost and modular design will allow the process to be easily replicated across the country on a variety of lands with otherwise marginal value. As such, the system can become the basis for a robust aquaculture and biofuels industry, leading to greater economic development in marginal communities and a source of sustainable products for the growing world population. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop a large-scale algal production system. Current methods of large-scale microalgae production are limited by technological problems, which prevent them from being reliable and scalable. These problems include frequent contamination, low productivity, and increased operating costs due to inefficient use of water and energy. The goals for our system are to maintain a low-density algal culture with high productivity for greater than two months without contamination, while requiring little or no additional cooling and CO2 supplementation.  With the use of a specially designed harvest apparatus, the plan is to perform periodic harvest cycles in order to maintain the culture in a low-density state.  Using gravity settling, the biomass will be concentrated by a factor of 100x prior to removal in order to minimize the loss of water from the system.  To characterize the performance of the system, cell growth rate, batch temperature, pH, and dissolved CO2 levels will be monitored.  Nitrogen/CO2 sparging tests will be used to determine the gas-liquid mass-transfer coefficient of the reactor.  Productivity rates will be compared with and without the supplementation of concentrated CO2, and culture purity will be assed daily via microscopy checks.

por.por_cntn:
The mission of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to enhance the productivity and profitability of large-scale algae cultivation via novel photo-bioreactor technologies and processes. With this goal in mind, we have created an algae cultivation system, which is based upon four main technical innovations. These include 1) a large volume/low density cultivation designed to boost productivity and lower operating costs, 2) the use of a disposable plastic vessel to mitigate contamination risk, 3) a reactor geometry and gas sparging system designed to prevent biofilm formation, and 4) the incorporation of a unique harvest apparatus, which allows for sterile removal of biomass with minimal water loss. To test for the technical and commercial feasibility of our concept, we decided to evaluate our photo-bioreactor systems ability to produce a high value pigment via the microalgae species Haematococcus pluvialis using a two stage process. In the green stage of this process, biomass accumulates in the presence of excess nutrients, but during the red stage, nutrient limitations and intense light exposure are required to induce synthesis of the secondary metabolite astaxanthin.

 

During operational testing performed in Phase 1, we were able to construct a 12,500 L plastic reactor bag and supporting structure, sterilize it, and use it to cultivate algae for 102 consecutive days without detrimental contamination. The integrated design of reactor geometry along with the gas sparging system performed exactly as planned for preventing biofilm formation.  We also met our target productivity of 6.1 g m-2d-1, while observing a rate as high as 11 g m-2d-1 in the latter part of the batch.  Moreover, the large heat capacity of the system allowed us to cultivate the cells without the use of extra energy for active heating and cooling.

 

Using our sterile harvest apparatus, we were able to make a total of 33 harvests over 143 days of green stage cultivation with no detrimental contamination (sum time of two reactors).  Our goal for the harvest apparatus was to collect a concentrated product stream of 10 g/L.  With only a very crude prototype, we achieved a peak harvest concentration of 4.9 g/L, which will be greatly improved with Phase II design modifications. The constructed prototype system had a reduced rate of water consumption during harvest (33 L/ m2/ Harvest), which given the initial charge volume of 775 L/m2, gave us a 3% lower rate of consumption than the tubular reactor used for comparison (25,000L, 46-cm Diameter) and 41% lower than an open raceway pond (15-cm depth) over a 104 day period. With further optimization we plan to reduce the initial charge volume and water consumption during harvest, to achieve 53% and 67% water savings in comparison to the tubular reactor and raceway ponds, respectively.

 

While green-stage algae cultivation of H. pluvialis was the focus of the Phase 1project, in Phase 1B our goal was to test the system for its capacity for red-stage algae cultivation, in which H. pluvialis is induced via stress factors to produce the commercially valuable nutraceutical astaxanthin. Our Phase 1B goal was to produce astaxanthin at a rate of 0.0478 g m-2d-1.  In the two red-stage cultivations we performed, the astaxanthin productivity was 0.0358 and 0.0413 g m-2d-1, but logistical and technical issues significantly hindered both of these batches.  With these issues simply resolved, we are confident that our system will easily surpass the target astaxanthin productivity.

 

The results of this project give a solid proof of concept of the significant potential of our novel technology for algae cultivation.  The strength of our design is in the conglomeration of many beneficial attributes.  These include, its large culture volume that allows for more stable temperatures between day and night time operations and the unique air sparger design, which prevents biofilm formation along the sides of the reactor and strips dissolved oxygen from the culture.  This maintains maximum light penetration throughout the life cycle of the system, and prevents the build up of inhibitory levels of DO that are seen in concentrated algae cultivations. The most important design feature of the system, however, is the harvest apparatus, which allows for removal of concentrated cells from the reactor floor.  This allows the culture to operate in a low density / high productivity state, and significantly reduces water consumption from harvesting. Especially promising are the high productivity levels observed in the late periods of the cultures, which give support to the merits of low-density cell cultivation.  Fundamentally, the design attributes of our photo-bioreactor are sound. While additional work is required for the goal of no CO2 supplementation, these issues are mainly associated with buffering chemistry and biology, and should be easily resolved with small lab-scale optimization studies.  Some challenges do remain, but the significant success of the Phase 1&1B projects clearly support advancement of this technology into Phase II development.
